The MartyrTitle Note [Criticism—Canonical] In his own copy of Battle-Pieces, Melville drew a line through the poem’s title. Howard P. Vincent argues that Melville did so “probably feeling that is [sic] was inflammatory and provocative” and not conducive to national healing (456). [Criticism—recent] [Intertextuality] Robillard prompts readers to compare Melville’s poem on Lincoln’s assassination to Walt Whitman’s “When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d” and “O Captain! My Captain!” (189). (Leslie McAbee)The Martyr Indicative of the passionPASSION [Denotation] As characterized by Melville's Webster’s dictionary of 1846, “passion” can refer to “[v]iolent agitation or excitement of mind, particularly such as is occasioned by an offense, injury or particularly such as is occasioned by an offense, injury or insult; hence, violent anger” (Webster, Noah, An American Dictionary of the English Language, 1846).
[Allusion—biblical] the “Passion” refers to the “last suffering of the Savior” (Webster), i.e. the physical, psychological, and spiritual suffering endured by Jesus from the Last Supper to his death; his Crucifixion.
(Leslie McAbee) of the people on the 15th of April, 1865[Poetics—form] [Criticism—canonical] Hennig Cohen identifies elements of the ballad form in the opening of the poem, which—he claims—“serves to infuse it with the depth and power of folk utterance.” Given the gravity of the poem’s subject, however, Cohen suggests the poem shifts “to a more elevated form, the choric dirge, which is also an appropriate expression of the mass psyche” (266).
[Intratextuality] Cohen points to Battle-Pieces poem “The Scout Toward Aldie” as another example of Melville’s “use of ballad conventions” (266). (Leslie McAbee) of the people on the 15th of April, 1865

Good Friday[Allusion--historical] President Lincoln was indeed assassinated on Good Friday of April 15th, 1865. (Leslie McAbee) was the day Of the prodigyPRODIGY [Definition] From the Latin (prodigium), Webster’s dictionary of 1846 defines “prodigy” as “[a]ny thing out of the ordinary process of nature” and as “[s]omething extraordinary, from which omens are drawn; portent” (Webster, Noah. An American Dictionary of the English Language. Harper & brothers, 1846.)
(Leslie McAbee) and crime, When they[Criticism--Recent] Stanton Garner notes that Melville levels blame for Lincoln's death on "they"--the South, rather than the assassin, John Wilkes Booth (Garner 386).
(Leslie McAbee) killed him in his pity, When they killed him in his primePRIME [Definition] In addition to referring to the “prime of life” or youth, “prime” also refers to the morning or dawn (Webster, Noah. An American Dictionary of the English Language, 1846.)
[Allusion—biblical] According to Mark 15:25, Christ was crucified at “the third hour” or about 9AM of the first day of Passover.
(Leslie McAbee) Of clemency and calm— When with yearning he was filled To redeem the evil-willed, And, though conqueror, be kind; But they killed him in his kindness, In their madness and their blindness, And they killed him from behind.
There is sobbing of the strong, And a pallPALL [Definition] Webster’s dictionary defines “pall” as both “[t]he cloth thrown over a dead body at funerals” and as a verb “to dispirit; to depress” (Webster, Noah. An American Dictionary of the English Language, 1846).
(Leslie McAbee) upon the land;AND A PALL UPON THE LAND [Allusion—biblical] The shrouding of the land in a “pall” connotes what the Synoptic Gospels describe as a three hour span of darkness during Jesus’ crucifixion. (See Matthew 27:45, Mark 15:33, Luke 23:44.)
(Leslie McAbee) But the People in their weeping Bare the iron hand: Beware the People weeping When they bare the iron hand.

He lieth in his blood— The father in his face; They have killed him, the Forgiver— The Avenger takes his place,[15] The Avenger wisely stern[Criticism--Recent] Stanton Garner identifies the "Avenger" as similar to "wise Draco" of the Battle-Pieces poem "The House-top" (Garner 386).
(Leslie McAbee), Who in righteousness shall do What the heavens call him to, And the parricides remand; For they killed him in his kindness, In their madness and their blindness, And his blood is on their hand.
There is sobbing of the strong, And a pall upon the land; But the People in their weeping Bare the iron hand: Beware the People weeping When they bare the iron hand.
